text: - [Rochak] Hello, everyone.
My name is Rochak Karki,

Security Specialist
Solutions Architect at AWS.
In this video, I'm going to demonstrate
Amazon Macie capability

that provides you
on-demand retrieval option

in the Macie console to
quickly investigate the data
that was identified as sensitive

from your Amazon Macie
sensitive data discovery jobs.
If you are not aware,
Amazon Macie is a data security service
that discovers sensitive data

using machine learning
and pattern matching,

provides feasibility
into data security risks,

and enables automated
protection against those risks.

Amazon Macie uses machine
learning and pattern matching

to discover sensitive data at
scale in a cost effective way.
Amazon Macie automatically detects a large
and growing list of sensitive data types,

including personally
identified information, PII,

such as names, addresses,
and credit card numbers.

It also gives you constant
visibility of your data
stored in Amazon's simple storage service.
So to show you the feature,
let's go to AWS Management Console.
I will select the Amazon Macie service
in the AWS Management Console.
When you go to Amazon Macie,

you will be presented
with this summary page.
So when the sensitive data is found,
we need to prioritize the action needed
on the specific buckets and objects.
We can take various actions
such as notifying the bucket owner,
changing configuration of the bucket,
or maybe even deleting the bucket.

Here we can see summary of
the buckets configuration,

such as if the buckets
is publicly accessible,

or if the encryption is
disabled for the bucket.

It also provides us
the findings, location,
and the amount of sensitive data found.

Amazon Macie does not
retrieve sensitive data

and store the actual contents
of your objects in S3

to help you meet your
compliance requirements.

So the reveal samples
features under the settings
provides us with a simple way to extract
which contents of an S3 object
were identified to be sensitive so we can

review, validate, and quickly
take action where needed.
Let's choose reveal samples.
We'll just click edit, then select enable,

and then we can specify how
we want to access S3 objects
to retrieve sensitive data samples.

We can assume an IAM role
or use AIM user credentials.

In this case, I have
selected assume an IAM role,

and I have selected the
role that I have created
for this purpose, Macie Reveal Role.
Then moving further down,
we can select KMS key for encryption.

I already have a KMS key created,
which I have selected here

as a Macie reveal key, and
then we'll click on save.

With that, we have enabled
reveal samples feature.
Please keep in mind that all data captured
with this feature is encrypted using

customer-managed AWS KMS keys
and is automatically deleted
after the examples are retrieved.

So once the feature is enabled,
let's go to the findings.

Here we can see we have
multiple data identifiers
that have found sensitive data.
Let's click on one of the finding.

In the finding page, we can
view details such as severity,
the region, account ID, resource,

and the time when it
was created and updated.
We can also view sensitive data types,

and we can also see the S3
bucket that was affected.
Under sensitive data section,
we can also see the total count
and also review besides reveal samples.
So if we click on review,
this will take us to the finding details

along with the sensitive
data that was found.
Here we can see the category of data type.
For this object, we have both
personal and financial information.

We can also see the finding
types from each category,

which in this case we can see
U.S. social security number
and credit card number.
Now let's click on reveal samples.

And this will show us
samples of the actual data.
With the data sample revealed,

we can confirm that there are
actual social security numbers
and credit card numbers in our S3 object.
Now that we have confirmed

the presence of sensitive
information in the S3 object,
we can take steps to remediate

based on our organization's
policies and procedures.
We won't cover remediation in this video.
With that being said, we saw today

that using Amazon Macie
reveal samples feature,

you can retrieve and reveal
samples of sensitive data

that Macie reports in individual
sensitive data findings.

This includes sensitive
data that Macie detects
using managed data identifiers
and data that matches the criteria
of custom data identifiers.
Please remember, before you can retrieve

and reveal sensitive data
samples for findings,
you need to configure and enable settings
for your Amazon Macie account.
When Amazon Macie extracts sensitive data

from an affected S3 object,
Macie encrypts the data
with an AWS key management service,
AWS KMS key that you specify,

temporarily stores the
encrypted data in a cache

and returns the data in your
results for the finding.
Also, Amazon Macie permanently deletes
the data from the cache

unless additional retention
is temporarily required
to resolve an operational issue.
To learn more about Amazon Macie,
please follow the link above.
Thank you and happy cloud computing.
